metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

knowledge_zone.heading: Unreliable Narrator: Creates meaning in the text

sections.content: Unreliable Narrator is used throughout the text to creates meaning in the text.

examples.quote: I wish you were all dead
examples.scene: Merricat shopping in the grocery store while villagers make hostile comments
examples.effect: Reveals Merricat's violent fantasies and disturbed mental state, establishing the gap between her perspective and normal social interaction

examples.quote: they seemed a little uneasy playing in front of our house
examples.scene: Merricat observing children playing on their lawn
examples.effect: Creates dramatic irony as Merricat's paranoid interpretation of innocent children playing reveals the gap between her perception and reality

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use Unreliable Narrator HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
